did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller gubernatorial records, William J. Ronan, Series 29

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Nelson A. Rockefeller served as governor of New York from January 1, 1959, to December 18, 1973. He was the first person elected to four consecutive four-year terms as a state governor.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into the following 6 subseries:

Subseries 1 - Human Rights Issues Subseries 2 - Reference Files Subseries 3 - Arthur Levitt Clippings Subseries 4 - Legislation Subseries 5 - Speeches and Statements Subseries 6 - General Correspondence

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: William J. Ronan (b. November 8, 1912) served as Secretary to Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller. He received his undergraduate degree magna cum laude at Syracuse University in 1934. He earned his Ph.D. in political science and economics at New York University. After graduating from NYU, Mr. Ronan taught there and served as administrative head of the Graduate Division of Public Service from 1939 to 1952. In 1953, he became Dean of the Graduate School of Public Administration and Social Service.

He served New York in several capacities prior to joining the Rockefeller administration. He was director of studies of the New York State Coordination Commission and conducted surveys of the State Education Department, the Civil Service Department, Public Authorities of New York State, the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles, and the nonjudicial positions in the state courts.

He became closely affiliated with Governor Rockefeller beginning in 1956, when Ronan served as the Executive Director of the Temporary State Commission on the Constitutional Convention and also of its successor organization, the Special Legislative Committee on Revision and Simplification of the Constitution. Ronan later became First Deputy City Administrator of the City of New York and served at the federal level with the Department of State and the Civil Service Commission. During his last two years as Governor Rockefeller's Secretary, Ronan also headed the Metropolitan Transit Authority.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: NOTE TO RESEARCHERS

This series contains office files of William J. Ronan. They document official activities in the execution of his duties as a member of Rockefeller's staff. The actions, decisions, and exchanges of information or points of view documented here occurred in the course of proposing and implementing policies for the Rockefeller administration, political campaigns, and/or Rockefeller's personal activities. However, unless a document is specifically addressed to or from Nelson A. Rockefeller, or is referred to in a document addressed to him, it should not be assumed he saw the document or was aware of its existence or substance. Furthermore, researchers should bear in mind that staff files may contain documents or drafts addressed to Rockefeller that were never shown to him.
SCOPE AND CONTENT

This series primarily covers the years when William Ronan served Nelson Rockefeller as Secretary to the Governor, 1959 to 1966. From 1965 to 1966, Ronan also served as head of the Metropolitan Transit Authority. The bulk of this series is composed of reports prepared for Governor Rockefeller by various state departments and agencies. Some of these reports duplicate those found in Record Group 15, Series 28, Departmental Reports.

did.unittitle: Human Rights Issues

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries is devoted to the issues of Human and Civil Rights. It covers all aspects from housing and unemployment discrimination to education and religion. An entire state agency focused on human rights, known as the State Commission Against Discrimination (SCAD) and later the State Commission for Human Rights (SCHR). This series is composed primarily of clippings, memoranda, and correspondence on various human rights topics that arose in the state.

did.unittitle: Reference Files

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by department or agency.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists primarily of the annual reports of individual state departments or agencies. While the Rockefeller administration did not begin until January 1, 1959, Ronan was sent annual reports of agencies for several years prior to its beginning. The subseries primarily covers the years 1959 through 1962. The final ten boxes of this subseries are an amalgam of publications covering a wide range of issues. The last box (box 47) contains primarily bound volumes of published reports.

Miscellaneous Publications
Arthur Levitt Clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prior to 1966, clippings were accumulated on Democrat Arthur Levitt, who was New York State Comptroller from 1955 to 1979. More than 1,300 clippings were sorted, numbered, and placed into the following eight categories: Politics (including Levitt's proposals and views, as well as political views and editorials on Levitt), Local Government, Taxation, Financing, Legislature (mostly criticism and comment of the New York State Legislature by Levitt), Audit and Control, Education, and Miscellaneous. Clippings were further subdivided by year. Some of the clippings were also categorized as "significant," indicating the articles contained something damaging to Levitt, particularly a reversal or modification of a previously stated view.

did.unittitle: Background Information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Document explaining procedure regarding collection of newspaper clippings, "over 1,300 clippings were sorted, numbered consecutively and placed into the following eight categories: Politics, Local Government, Taxation, Financing, Legislature, Audit and Control, Education, Miscellaneous."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a partial selection of legislative proposals submitted to Nelson A. Rockefeller. It contains copies of memoranda explaining Governor Rockefeller's reasoning for either vetoing or approving a particular piece of legislation. Also found in this subseries are legislative proposals for specific state agencies or departments for 1964.
